nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Arrival for the Weekend
nodes.text: The doorbell rings. Your child is here for the weekend. Your partner stands a few steps behind you, suddenly very interested in the hallway plant. You can feel the tension between wanting things to be warm… and not wanting anything to feel forced.

choices.label: Invite your partner to come to the door with you.
choices.text: You turn and say quietly: “Come with me, it’s okay. We’re doing this together.”

choices.label: Go alone and keep your partner in the background.
choices.text: You open the door alone. “Hey buddy, I’m so glad you’re here.” Your partner stays out of sight.

choices.label: Let your partner open the door first.
choices.text: You gesture to your partner: “You open, I’ll grab the bag.” The child sees them first, reading their face for clues.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: First Minutes Together
nodes.text: Shoes are half on, half off. The weekend bag is spilling clothes. Your partner tries a friendly smile and says, “Hey, it’s good to see you again.” The child answers with a mumble and keeps their eyes on you.

choices.label: Bridge the interaction gently.
choices.text: “You remember Alex, right? They made that silly pancake last time.” You give the child a small smile and stay close.

choices.label: Let the silence sit and hope it fixes itself.
choices.text: You busy yourself with the bag, pretending not to notice the tension.

choices.label: Pressure the child to be more polite.
choices.text: “Hey, say hello properly. That’s rude.” The child stiffens and looks smaller.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: The First Micro-Conflict
nodes.text: Later, the child flops onto the couch with a tablet. Your partner glances at the clock. “Didn’t you say screen time is limited on weekends?” The child hears it and clutches the tablet a little tighter.

choices.label: Align with your partner in front of the child.
choices.text: “Yeah, we did say that. Let’s do 20 more minutes, then we pick a game together.” You say it calmly, staying next to the child.

choices.label: Undermine your partner to keep the peace with the child.
choices.text: “It’s fine, it’s just this once.” Your partner goes quiet, hurt flickering across their face.

choices.label: Ask for a quick sidebar with your partner.
choices.text: “Give me a second.” You step into the kitchen with your partner to talk out of earshot.

nodes.speaker: Partner
nodes.title: Between You and Your Partner
nodes.text: “I’m trying to help,” your partner says quietly. “But sometimes I feel like the bad cop, or like I should just stay out of it.” The words land heavier than they sound.

choices.label: Validate their effort and define a shared role.
choices.text: “I know this is tough. I do want you involved — we just need to agree how we do it so our child doesn’t feel ganged up on.”

choices.label: Ask them to back off for now.
choices.text: “Maybe just let me handle discipline this weekend. It’s still new for them.”

choices.label: Get defensive about their complaint.
choices.text: “You’re not the only one who has feelings here. I’m stuck in the middle all the time.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Act 1 – The Triangle Appears
nodes.text: By evening, one thing is clear: this isn’t just between you and your child anymore. Every small decision now moves inside a triangle — you, your partner, and a kid who is still figuring out where it’s safe to land.

choices.label: Take a quiet moment to reflect.
choices.text: You step into the bathroom or balcony, just to breathe and notice how the day actually felt.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You mentally bookmark the day and move on for now.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Quick Reflection
nodes.text: When you replay the day, what stands out more — the awkward moments, or the fact that everyone is still trying to fit into a new shape of “family”?

choices.label: Notice the attempts to connect.
choices.text: You register the small efforts — the partner’s smile, the child’s glance, your own choices to slow down instead of explode.

choices.label: Notice how stretched you feel.
choices.text: You admit to yourself that standing between partner, child, and co-parent is exhausting — and that you’ll need support, not just willpower.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Dinner Tension
nodes.text: Later that evening, the child sits at the table pushing vegetables around the plate. Your partner quietly says, “We agreed we’d all eat the same meal, remember?” The child freezes. You feel the familiar pull — between protecting the child and supporting your partner.

choices.label: Back up your partner kindly.
choices.text: “Hey sweetheart, let’s try a few bites together. Then we can pick something else if you need to.”

choices.label: Side with the child to avoid a blow-up.
choices.text: “It’s fine, today’s been a lot. They don’t have to eat it.” Your partner immediately deflates.

choices.label: Ask for a quick reset between you and your partner.
choices.text: “Give me a second.” You gesture your partner into the hallway for a whisper-talk.

nodes.speaker: Partner
nodes.title: What’s Really Happening
nodes.text: Your partner’s voice is tight. “I’m trying to help give the kid structure… but every time I say something, I feel like the outsider. Like I’m just here to observe — not actually parent.”

choices.label: Reassure and clarify the roles.
choices.text: “You’re not an outsider. You matter here — we just need steady signals for the kid to understand everyone’s place.”

choices.label: Defend the child instead, without addressing partner’s insecurity.
choices.text: “They’re going through a lot. You need to give them space.”

choices.label: Admit you feel torn too.
choices.text: “Honestly? I feel stuck in the middle. I want to support you — and keep things safe for them.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Unexpected Comment From the Child
nodes.text: From the dining room you hear a small voice: “Why do you always listen to them more than to me?” The question hits harder than expected.

choices.label: Reassure the child directly.
choices.text: You kneel beside them: “I always listen to you. Sometimes grownups talk to figure things out too.”

choices.label: Ask your partner to step back for a moment.
choices.text: “Give us a minute.” Your partner nods, quietly leaving the room.

choices.label: Minimize the child’s concern to avoid drama.
choices.text: “That’s not true, you’re overreacting.” The child shrinks back slightly.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: A Line in the Sand
nodes.text: The three of you sit in the living room — an uncomfortable triangle. Everyone’s emotions are simmering. Something needs to be named clearly, or this dynamic will repeat every weekend.

choices.label: Establish a simple house-rules framework.
choices.text: “Let’s agree on three rules — not ten — just the basics. Same rules for everyone, including us.”

choices.label: Ask your partner to step into a secondary role temporarily.
choices.text: “I think it’s better if I handle discipline for now — until the kid feels more secure.”

choices.label: Let the conflict fade without addressing it.
choices.text: You change the subject and let everyone drift into separate corners of the house.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Act 2 — A Small Step Toward Stability
nodes.text: The house quiets down. Small progress or small fractures — either way, the shape of the family is changing. Slowly.

choices.label: Continue to Act 3 — Loyalty Binds
choices.text: Each bond pulls in a different direction.

choices.label: Return to Menu
choices.text: Pause the scene here.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Back From the Other Home
nodes.text: The front door clicks. Your child comes back from time with the other parent. Shoes half-off, backpack half-open. They drop their things and say casually: “Mama/Tata said I don’t have to listen to [Partner’s name] if I don’t want to.” The words land like a stone.

choices.label: Stay curious instead of reacting.
choices.text: “Oh? What exactly did they say?” You keep your voice calm, even though your chest tightens.

choices.label: Defend your partner immediately.
choices.text: “That’s not okay to say. [Partner] is an adult in this house and deserves respect.”

choices.label: Brush it off with a joke.
choices.text: “Wow, sounds like a lot of bosses in your life, huh?” You chuckle, but the knot stays.

nodes.speaker: Partner
nodes.title: The Sting
nodes.text: Later, in the kitchen, your partner speaks quietly, not looking at you: “So… I’m the optional adult now? That’s how it is?” There’s hurt underneath the sarcasm.

choices.label: Validate their feelings and name the dynamic.
choices.text: “It hurts, I get that. This is a loyalty thing, not a verdict on you. We’re in the middle of their tug-of-war.”

choices.label: Minimize it to keep peace.
choices.text: “Don’t take it so personally. Kids say stuff.”

choices.label: Shift to problem-solving immediately.
choices.text: “Okay, yes, that sucks. Let’s figure out how we respond next time together.”

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: The Message
nodes.text: Your phone buzzes. A new message from your ex: “I heard [Partner] is telling our child what to do again. They’re NOT a parent. I won’t let them replace me.” The familiar wave of anger and exhaustion rises.

choices.label: Set a clear boundary around respect.
choices.text: You type: “No one is replacing you. But in this home, all adults treat each other with respect — especially in front of our child.”

choices.label: Defend your partner aggressively.
choices.text: You fire back: “Maybe if you were more consistent, [Partner] wouldn’t have to pick up the slack.”

choices.label: Avoid the conflict for now.
choices.text: You leave the message on read, telling yourself you’ll deal with it “later”.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Act 3 — Invisible Lines
nodes.text: As the night settles, you notice how many invisible lines criss-cross this family: who is “real”, who is “optional”, who gets loyalty when people feel scared. You can’t erase the lines — but you can choose how you walk them.

choices.label: Continue to Act 4 — Shared vs. Separate Teams
choices.text: You get ready to look at how to build a team without erasing anyone.
